answers: Switzerland [or Confederation Suisse; or Confederazione Elvetica; or Confederazione Svizzera; or Helvetia; or Swiss Confederation; or Helvetic Confederation]
parts: Name this lake with four glaciated valleys, connected by narrow channels. One man legendarily lept from a boat on this lake to escape Gessler.
Four of this country’s cantons have a border on Lake Lucerne, including Nidwalden, Uri, and Schwyz.
A long line of cement defensive wedges called the Promenthouse Line, on the west side of Switzerland, is nicknamed after this candy that it resembles.

answers: Maximilien Robespierre [or Maximilien François Marie Isidore de Robespierre]
Committee of Public Safety [or Comité de salut publique]
Society of the Jacobins [or Society of the Friends of the Constitution; or Friends of Freedom and Equality; or the Jacobin Club] <John John Groger>/<ed. JO>
parts: Name this rival of Georges Danton, who led the Reign of Terror during the French Revolution.
Robespierre was the head of this body, which carried out the September Massacres and executed thousands by the guillotine.
Robespierre was a member of this radical faction, which grew out of The Mountain and opposed the Girondins [“Jee-ron-dins”].

answers: Flannery O’Connor [or Mary Flannery O’Connor] <Carrie Derner>/<ed. ME>
parts: Name this short story about Phoenix Jackson, who travels down the title road to get medicine for her grandson.
This Southern Gothic author of “A Worn Path” wrote about Laurel Hand and Fay McKelva in The Optimist’s Daughter.
This other Southern Gothic author wrote about the Grandmother and her family dying at the hands of The Misfit in “A Good Man is Hard to Find.”

answers: the Dominican Order [or Order of Preachers]
Saint Ignatius of Loyola <Spencer Johnson>/<ed. AR>
parts: Name this set of Catholic orders. This group's namesake and founder, who was from Assisi, lived a life of poverty and allegedly pacified a wolf.
Thomas Aquinas and Albertus Magnus were both members of this group currently headed by Bruno Cadoré. Members of this order are known as Jacobins in France.
Another prominent order, the Society of Jesus, was founded by this Spanish priest. This saint collected contemplations and prayers in his Spiritual Exercises.
Name this weakly radioactive, silvery metal. This element’s dioxide was formerly added to glass during manufacture to increase the refractive index for use in high-quality camera lenses.
Thorium belongs to this group of elements. This group is located on the f-block, below the lanthanides in the periodic table.
The only naturally found actinides are thorium and this other element. This element is found in yellowcake, and it is separated into its 235 and 238 isotopes through gas centrifugation.

answers: The Treachery of Images [or La trahison des images; or The Treason of Images; or The Wind and the Song]
René Magritte [or Rene Francois Ghislain Magritte]
Not to be Reproduced [or La reproduction interdite] <Jonathan Amlong>/<ed. CW>
parts: In this painting, a brown pipe with a tan background floats above words that translate to “This is not a Pipe” The artist argued that the caption is true because it is simply a painting of a pipe and not the actual object of a pipe.
This surrealist artist of The Treachery of Images also painted men with bowler hats floating in the air in Golconda.
This other painting by Magritte features a man looking into a mirror, only to see the back of his head reflected, rather than his face.

answers: commensalism [prompt, but do not otherwise reveal, symbiosis]
parts: Name this kind of relationship between two organisms where one organism benefits while the other is unharmed.
Commensalism, like parasitism and mutualism, is a form of this general interaction that exists between two species in which at least one benefits.
A form of commensalism involves this kind of rootless plant, which grows upon another plant or object for physical support. Examples of these non-parasitic plants include orchids and mosses.

answers: the Sublime [or the Beautiful and the Sublime]
George Santayana [or Jorge Agustín Nicolás Ruiz de Santayana] <Spencer Johnson>/<ed. HB>
parts: Name this subject of Kant’s Critique of Judgment. It is the philosophical study of beauty and art.
Kant defines this term as “what is absolutely great,” and distinguishes it from the beautiful. In a 1757 treatise, Edmund Burke called this concept the “strongest emotion.”

This author says that terror is sometimes mistakenly regarded as the sublime’s essence rather than its cause in his book The Sense of Beauty. This philosopher also wrote The Last Puritan and The Realms of Being.

answers: The Red and the Black: A Chronicle of the 19th Century [or The Scarlet and the Black; or Le Rouge et le Noir: Chronique du XIXe siécle]
parts: Name this novel in which Julian Sorel shoots Madame de Renal after she prevents him from marrying Mathilde.
This 19th century French author wrote The Red and the Black.
In Stendhal’s The Charterhouse of Parma, Frabrizio del Dongo fights in this battle. George Osborne dies at this battle in Vanity Fair.

answers: The Championships, Wimbledon [prompt on The Championships]
Pete Sampras [or Petros Sampras] <Tyler Benedict>/<ed. SP>/<ed. JO>
parts: Name this tradition-laden athletic championship, played at the All England Club since 1877. Competitors must follow a strict dress code of all-white or near-white clothing.
This man defeated Marin Čilić [“Sill-itch”] in 2017 to win his record 8th championship in Gentlemen’s Singles. This Swiss tennis player has also captured an all-time best 19 Grand Slam titles.
Before Federer won his 8th Wimbledon championship this year, he was tied in the record books with this American star, who won 7 Wimbledons in 8 years from 1993 to 2000.

answers: Euphrates River [or Buranunu; or Firat Nehri; or Nahr al Furat; or Perath; or Purattu; or Ufrat]
parts: Name this Islamic Caliphate, which lost much of its influence to the Abbasids after the Battle of Zab.
Yazid I of the Umayyads defeated a small army belonging to Muhammad's grandson at Karbala, which is near this river. This river roughly parallels the Tigris River.
Córdoba was held under Islamic control until Christian forces reclaimed it in this process. This process of Muslim expulsion from Spain was completed with the fall of Granada in 1492.
Name this process, that moves heat by bulk fluid motion.
Marangoni convection causes “teardrops” to form in partially-filled wine glasses due to the different values for this quantity for water and ethanol.
This dimensionless quantity, the product of the Prandtl and Grashof numbers, determines whether a fluid is undergoing conduction or convection.
Name this technique, by which an actor uses intense emotional recall of personal experiences to emotionally identify with their character. Daniel Day-Lewis practices this technique.
This Russian director first described method acting as a “system” in his book An Actor Prepares.
Stanislavsky collaborated with Edward Craig in a production of this play in Moscow in 1911. Craig’s set included sheets of gauze that fell away after Claudius’ exit from the first court scene.

answers: Progressive Party [or Bull Moose Party] <David Dennis>/<ed. JO>
parts: Name this Nativist, anti-immigrant and anti-Catholic party, which ran former President Millard Fillmore as its candidate for President in 1856.
The anti-slavery Free Soil Party ran this former President on their first ticket in 1848. The administration of this successor of Andrew Jackson was plagued by the panic of 1837.
This political party nominated Henry Wallace and Robert LaFollete as its candidates for President.
Name this novel about Winston and Julia’s attempt to rebel against the totalitarian government of Oceania.
This author of 1984, also wrote of the power struggle between the pigs Napoleon and Snowball in Animal Farm.
Orwell also wrote this nonfiction account of his time fighting with the POUM against the Nationalist government of Spain.

answers: Lochner v. New York [or New York v. Lochner]
Oliver Wendell Holmes, Jr. <Cole Phinney>/<ed. SP>/<ed. JO>
parts: Name this progressive-era case, which upheld the "liberty of contract" in ruling against limiting the hours that bakers could work.
The majority opinion of Lochner v. New York cited the due process clause of this amendment, which guarantees that states provide “equal protection” under the laws.

This Supreme Court Justice declared that “the Fourteenth Amendment does not enact Herbert Spencer’s Social Statics” in his dissenting opinion in Lochner v. New York.  He is also known for the “clear and present danger” test from his opinion in Schenck v. United States.
Name this Italian Renaissance composer, who is likely more famous for the murder of his wife and her lover in 1590.
As a composer, Gesualdo was known for using heavy chromaticism in this secular polyphonic form often contrasted with motets.  Claudio Monteverdi wrote nine books of these.
This composer's ballet Monumentum pro Gesualdo consisted of his own orchestrations of Gesualdo’s madrigals. This composer’s other ballets include The Rite of Spring.
Name this title character, who becomes king after assassinating Duncan in a Shakespeare play.
Three witches prophesize that this character will be “lesser than Macbeth, and greater” and that he will father kings. He is murdered by three men hired by Macbeth.
This son of Banquo is told to “fly, fly, fly” and successfully escapes the murderers’ attempts to kill him.
Name this first stage of mitosis, wherein the nucleolus disintegrates and the chromatin coils into chromosomes.
As the cell moves into the prometaphase stage, this compacted region holds the two identical sister chromatids together. It is usually found in the middle of a chromosome.
These protein structures near the centromeres are where the mitotic spindle fibers attach, allowing the chromatids to separate during anaphase.
Name this god, who was burnt on the ship Hringhorni after his brother Hodr accidentally killed him with mistletoe.
Baldr was given the opportunity to return to leave Hel if all beings wept for him, but he will remain dead until Ragnarok because this giantess refused to weep for him.
Hodr was given the mistletoe by this god. Thokk may have been this Norse trickster god in disguise, according to some sources.
